title: Are we truly only responsible for our own actions or are we responsible for the actions of others who have been dead for over 40 years? - Quora

response.answer_text: A good question, and I think I know how most Americans would answer (“No!” or something more pungent). But I want to offer a different view. I think there are different kinds of responsibilities and different degrees of responsibility, and we may well be responsible somewhat for others’ actions long ago. To explain: Different kinds: Legal responsibility and moral responsibility are not the same; you can be legally blameless and morally culpable, when a moral harm isn’t illegal. Likewise, responsibility for identifiable actions is different from responsibility for maintaining or supporting behavior, and both from intentions, beliefs and attitudes. Then there is an important distinction among committing an action and enabling it. Different degrees: Some may think everyone involved in any way in some action is equally responsible, but I think there are different degrees, with some bearing more responsibility and some less. Putting this together: Obviously you didn’t commit actions that happened before you were born, or now without your awareness or active participation. So you don’t have the primary responsibility for those actions. But what if you benefited or profited from those actions, have accepted those benefits and profits, and refuse to make things right with the injured parties when you can? What if you refuse to consider whether you are responsible, seeking refuge in feigned ignorance? I think you still bear some responsibility for those past or remote actions (by others) due to your current actions. Also, overt action or behavior isn’t the only thing for which we are responsible morally (in distinction from legally). We are also responsible for what we think, for our beliefs, attitudes, judgments that maybe only we (and God) know. So sympathy with some past wrong action makes one morally responsible for that action, even if not to the same degree as the person who actually committed it. The great example for Americans today, of course, is current responsibility for the horrors of slavery and its lingering effects in our society. I know there is a strong urge to claim immunity from any responsibility by actions of our ancestors; we all want to think well of ourselves. But whites are currently benefiting from the lingering effects of white supremacy run amok, and I think they bear considerable responsibility for making things right, or at least better.

I don't think we can reasonably be prrsonally responsible for the actions of others that occurred in the past . However , I do think that if we hold office in an organization or institution where great wrongs occurred under previous leadership , then the current leadership has a duty to deal with any present consequences of past organizational or institutional wrongs. The reason for this is that the organization or institution as an enduring entity still exists and carries along with its ongoing existence the legacy of its past . Not knowing the specific context you had in mind for your question I might make a guess that perhaps you were wondering about the conflictual issues around racial justice affecting the U.S. presently ? Many people believe that the U.S. owes the present decendents of African American slaves some form of reparations . The U.S. is an enduring entity and therefore , does carry forward the legacy of its past. Furthermore , there really is no one in the U.S. on either side of the argument that doesn't recognize that slavery was a great sin of the past. So, strictly from these observations it seems that the government does need to deal with the present consequences of this sin. However , the American government is said to be “of the people and for the people . “ The implication is that the government works on behalf of the people and the people sanction the government . Now who is responsible - all Americans ? There are many other factors impinging on the overall conflict, but, this discussion was specifically trying to provide a thoughtful answer to your question .

Are we truly only responsible for our own actions or are we responsible for the actions of others who have been dead for over 40 years? Responsible for the actions of others dead for 40 years? I’m not. I’ve never been found responsible for the actions of anyone even recently dead. Or for that matter, anyone else alive - anyone other than myself. Oh, sure in certain teamwork setups, multiple people take on responsibility for a shared area. Share blame and credit as they rely on each others’s diligence. It’s our own actions and statements we’re most naturally concerned in. Partly because we’re most readily implicated in them. Where others question or challenge us on what we’ve ourselves done or said, and we can’t respond (or won’t) - our denial of responsibility will not leave people saying “Oh, you aren’t responsible!” They’ll say “You’re irresponsible.” It pains me to say this, but we’re really only responsible for whatever we take on. Consequence is not the same as responsibility. Where we wrong others we find the consequence, either in how they treat us or how they no longer wish to treat us. In certain cases, when they appeal to law for redress. In the informal case they’re free to choose whatever they’ll give of themselves, and to whom. Decide what they’ll take, too. And what of themselves they’ll take away. Our responsibility not required. In the civil or criminal case we may be made liable to punishment. This is sometimes called “being made responsible.” It isn’t. It’s just consequence. Consequence comes down regardless of how responsible or irresponsible we are. Point is. Tons of people don’t take responsibility for what they do. They deny, excuse, justify - they refuse. They’ll claim they couldn’t do anything, or otherwise. Often enough, to sell their denial they refuse to do anything at all. To prove their powerlessness, they deny even the control they have. They’re not found “not responsible,” they’re found irresponsible. But we have whatever responsibility we take on. We look around the world, see what’s fair and what’s tragic, and what could be better, and what we could do. We take on responsibility for what wasn’t ours. We take it on. We make it ours. If nobody took on responsibility for what people forty years dead left to us, the world would have fallen apart. We take it on. We make it ours. We are responsible by right of possession. Not responsible for what was done. Responsible for what we’ll do with it now. Or as we wish - not responsible. Irresponsible. Me, I’m responsible for the universe. But I won’t fight you for the part you’ve taken on, to be responsible for. Hell, I’m glad you have.

Morally you are responsible and accountable only for your actions, and not of your forebears. But legally, you may have to perform certain obligations and duties which your forebears had, but could not or did not, for as long as the means and resources to accomplish these are with you or owned by you.

Yes, we are. Baha’u’llah, Prophet-Founder of the Baha’i Faith, says people should see with their own eyes, not through the eyes of others, and hear with their own ears, not through the ears of others. No, we are not responsible for the actions of others who have been dead for 40 years.

We are only responsible for our own actions, and those under our direct care, such as children. I can take pride in my heritage if it's good stuff, or denounce evils done by ancestors, but I owe nobody anything for what someone else did before me.

You're responsible for your own actions and that of minor children…..no you can not be held responsible for something someone did or didnt do 40 years ago.. Which is what I say when black people bring up slavery…
